title: San Francisco 49ers shut down Jared Goff and keep the Los Angeles Rams reeling
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL headlines. USA TODAY

LOS ANGELES -- Here are three things we learned from the Coliseum after the Los Angeles Rams’ 20-7 loss to San Francisco on Sunday.

1. After winning the NFC West by two and three games, respectively, the past two seasons, the Rams find themselves in a new position under third-year head coach Sean McVay.

Looking up in the divisional standings.

On their first three-game losing streak under McVay, the Rams (3-3) are now three games in the loss column behind first-place San Francisco (5-0).

They’ve also lost head to head to both teams they’re now chasing, the 49ers and second-place Seattle (4-1), making the hill to climb that much steeper.

2. With star running back Todd Gurley shelved with a quadriceps injury, the Rams running game shone for exactly one series.

49ers tight end George Kittle (85) stiff arms Rams cornerback Marcus Peters during the first half at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. (Photo: Orlando Ramirez, USA TODAY Sports)

Los Angeles took the opening kickoff and drove 56 yards on seven plays — all runs — to take a 7-0 lead on Robert Woods’ 8-yard end around

The Rams mustered just 36 yards of total offense on their next six possessions as San Francisco built a 17-7 lead after three quarters.

Rookie Darryl Henderson briefly sparkled in the second quarter, racing to gains of 22 and 14 yards on his first two touches — the second and third carries of his NFL career — to move the Rams into the red zone.

But the third-round pick out of Memphis dropped a pitch on the opening play of the second half, setting up the 1-yard Jimmy Garappolo touchdown sneak, and was stopped on fourth and 1 early in the fourth quarter.

3. Just two weeks after throwing for a career-high 517 yards in the home loss to Tampa Bay, Los Angeles quarterback Jared Goff set a career low with just 78 yards passing against San Francisco.

That was due to Los Angeles' on-going struggles up front.

Goff was sacked four times by the San Francisco defensive front, as the Rams offensive line continued to struggle in protection with first-year starters Brian Allen and Joe Noteboom at center and left guard, respectively.

To make matters worse, Noteboom was helped off the field with a leg injury and carted to the locker room. He was replaced by fellow second-year interior lineman Jamil Demby.

Goff's previous career low was 90, also in a home loss to San Francisco, in the penultimate start of his ugly rookie year on Dec. 24, 2016.

Joe Curley is a staff writer with the Ventura County Star. Follow him on Twitter, Instagram and Snapchat @vcsjoecurley.
description: On their first three-game losing streak under Sean McVay, the Rams (3-3) are three games in the loss column behind first-place San Francisco (5-0).
